p: As far as we know, no report is present in the literature on the biological activity of S. dentata EO. Only S. aurea EO was the subject of a few studies for its biological activity. The first one dates back to 1998 when Bisio and collaborators investigated its antimicrobial activity [ 33]. The authors tested this oil on 13 microorganisms. They found a nonsignificant effect on Gram-positive bacteria, especially S. aureus. These results were confirmed in this work. Later on, Russo tested the oil firstly on human melanoma cells (M14, A2058 and A375) [ 34] and then on prostate cancer [ 35]. In both works, the author affirmed the inhibition of growth and an apoptotic effect on all the tested cells.
